title: 105_hr2588
content:
The "Border Security and Enforcement Act of 1997" establishes the Office of Enforcement and Border Affairs within the Department of Justice. The Director of this office is appointed by the President and reports directly to the Attorney General. The Director's functions are outlined in the Act. SEC. 3. TRANSFER OF FUNCTIONS. Functions from the Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to the Director include Border Patrol, detention and deportation, intelligence, investigations, and inspections programs. SEC. 4. REFERENCES. This section clarifies that references to the head of an office or the office itself in any federal law or document are deemed to refer to the new office to which a function is transferred. SEC. 5. EXERCISE OF AUTHORITIES. SEC. 5. EXERCISE OF AUTHORITIES. A Federal official can exercise all authorities under any other provision of law for performing a function transferred by this Act. SEC. 6. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. Legal Documents such as orders, rules, permits, contracts, and licenses issued by specified government officials or courts in the performance of transferred functions under this Act are included in the transfer. These documents must be in effect on the effective date of the transfer. The Act ensures that legal documents issued by government officials or courts will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or a court of competent jurisdiction. It also states that any pending proceedings or applications for benefits, services, licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. The Act ensures that legal documents remain valid until modified or revoked by authorized officials or a court. It also specifies that ongoing suits will proceed as if the Act had not been enacted. No actions against the Department of Justice or Immigration and Naturalization Service will be affected by the Act. The Act ensures that legal documents remain valid until modified or revoked by authorized officials or a court. Ongoing suits involving government officers will continue with the new officer or office responsible for the function. Statutory requirements for administrative and judicial procedures apply to transferred functions under the Act. SEC. 7. TRANSFER AND ALLOCATION OF APPROPRIATIONS AND PERSONNEL. The Department of Justice personnel and assets related to functions transferred by the Act will be moved to the Office of Enforcement and Border Affairs for allocation. Unexpended funds must be used for their original purposes. Personnel transfers under the Act exclude special Government employees. Personnel transfers to the Office of Enforcement and Border Affairs must not result in separation or reduction in grade or compensation for one year. Those holding Executive Schedule positions before the Act will continue to be compensated at not less than their previous rate in the new position. Personnel transferred to the Office of Enforcement and Border Affairs must maintain their grade and compensation for one year in the new position. SEC. 8. DELEGATION AND ASSIGNMENT. Functions transferred under this Act can be delegated by the official to designated officers and employees. Responsibility for the function remains with the official. SEC. 9. AUTHORITY OF DIRECTOR OF THE OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET WITH RESPECT TO FUNCTIONS TRANSFERRED. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will determine functions transferred under the Act and make necessary incidental transfers of personnel, assets, liabilities, grants, contracts, and funds to carry out the provisions of the Act. Further measures and dispositions will be provided as necessary to achieve the Act's purposes. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS.

    The term ``Director'' refers to the Director of the Office of Enforcement and Border Affairs. 
    The term ``function'' encompasses various duties, powers, and activities. 
    The term ``office'' includes different organizational entities.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE.

    This Act will be effective on October 1, 1999.
